thread.title: Big things grow from short film
thread.title_full: Big things grow from short film

title: Big things grow from short film
text:
Big things grow from short film with Screen Australia grant by: What are these? Tasmanian film-maker Neil Triffett has a Screen Australia grant to make a feature film. Picture: NICOLE CLEARY Source: News Corp Australia 
TASMANIAN-born writer and director Neil Triffett is to turn his modern take on a Romeo and Juliet-themed short film into a large-scale feature, thanks to a Screen Australia funding grant. 
Emo is a musical film that follows the twisted Romeo and Juliet love story of Ethan the emo and Trinity, an enthusiastic and faithful Christian. 
The planned feature has a budget close to $2 million, with $500,000 contibuted by Screen Australia. 
Emo began life as a 15-minute short film in 2013 and was made for $10,000. 
It was shot in just one week around various Victorian sites. 
Mr Triffett’s feature will last 90 minutes and will be a satirical high school musical about a group of misfits, a coming-of-age romance and a turf war. 
It will be a film for anyone who has the feeling at some point in their life that they don’t fit in, Mr Triffett said.
